awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A Chemoproteomic Strategy to Decipher Epitranscriptomic Pyrimidine Modifications
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to understand how ribonucleic acid (RNA) chemistry affects fundamental biological processes. Recent evidence has indicated that enzyme-installed modifications on RNA can regulate how genes are expressed in cells; however, there are major gaps in our understanding of this phenomenon, including which RNA molecules are modified, which enzymes catalyze the modifications, and how these modifications affect RNA function. This project seeks to address these questions through the application of innovative approaches integrating chemistry and biology, and will provide unique training opportunities for students at the interface of these disciplines. The research is also combined with an education and outreach plan aimed at broadening secondary school and undergraduate level engagement with nucleic acid chemistry and biology. These efforts will include the development of a video-based series aimed at disseminating landmark results in the primary scientific literature to New Jersey high school students. 

Epitranscriptomic modifications on eukaryotic mRNA have been implicated in gene expression regulation. In particular, a diverse set of chemical modifications of cytosine are known to exist in mRNA, but a definitive understanding of the distribution of these marks, the enzymes that mediate their installation, and ultimately their biological function, is lacking. This project aims to address these questions by developing metabolically-incorporated chemical probes to capture RNA cytosine-modifying enzyme activity in cells. The probes will be integrated with proteomic and transcriptomic workflows and genetic perturbations in order to profile relevant RNA modifying enzymes, map their cellular substrates, identify reader proteins, and interrogate the functional consequences of cytosine modifications on mRNA behavior. Together, these research approaches will reveal insights into the regulation of cellular RNA through enzymatic modification and provide powerful tools for probing RNA modifications in diverse biological contexts.

This project is jointly funded by the Genetic Mechanisms cluster in the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Division, and the Chemistry of Life Processes program in the Chemistry Division.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
The research goals of this project were to develop new methodology to study epitranscriptomic RNA modifications in mammals. RNA modifications are ubiquitous in biology, but we lack robust approaches to map RNA modification sites and characterize enzymes that are responsible for regulating modification levels. Such methods are critical for mapping the chemical diversity present across all RNA species to understand how RNA modifications regulate RNA behavior and cellular function.

During this project, we developed a chemical strategy which we named RNA-mediated activity-based protein profiling (RNABPP), which enables global characterization of RNA modifying enzymes in cells. This strategy combines modified nucleoside probes that are metabolically fed to cells with RNA-protein enrichment methods and quantitative mass spectrometry. Using several distinct modified nucleoside probe structures, we were able to identify and characterize human RNA modifying enzymes including methyltransferases, dioxygenases, and dihydrouridine synthases (DUS). In particular, our RNABPP method developed new chemical probes for ALKBH1, a human RNA modifying enzyme that performs oxidation chemistry on cytidine bases, and enzymes from the DUS family -- DUS1L, DUS2L, DUS3L, and DUS4L, which perform reduction of uridine to dihydrouridine. With new chemical probes in hand, we were able to perform the first unbiased identification of the substrates of these RNA modifying enzymes in cells. Our work with human DUS3L established that this enzyme installs dihydrouridine in the variable loop of cytosolic human tRNAs.

Further, we generated genetic knockout models of human DUS genes and characterized effects on cell growth, protein translation, and RNA stability. These proteins had been previously studied in bacteria and yeast, but insights into their role in mammalian biology are lacking. We found that human cells lacking DUS genes were impaired in growth and protein translation efficiency. We also identified defects in translation of specific mRNA codons. Taken together, these studies lay the groundwork for mechanistic investigation of human DUS proteins and their associated dihydrouridine RNA modifications.

Separately, we showed that modified nucleosides from our RNABPP strategy could be applied in synthetic RNAs to investigate the biochemical principles of RNA substrate recognition and modification by human DUS enzymes. We studied human DUS2L using this approach and developed a biochemical model underlying its substrate selection and installation of dihydrouridine at specific sites on human tRNAs. We expect that our nucleoside probes can be applied broadly for biochemical and structural studies of RNA modifying enzymes in complex with their RNA substrates.

Together with the research outcomes from this project, which have advanced our understanding of the distribution and function of RNA pyrimidine modifications, this work has provided enabling research tools which are anticipated to have a broader impact on the study of RNA epitranscriptomics. Developing such methodologies is in line with a recent report from the National Academies of Science, Engineering, and Medicine that highlights the significant need for characterizing RNA modifications to accelerate advances in biological understanding, medicine, and agriculture. Additionally, this project made contributions to the STEM workforce in the training of undergraduate students, PhD students, and postdoctoral fellows in the area of nucleic acid chemical biology. These trainees have received interdisciplinary training in chemistry and biology research, science communication, manuscript and proposal writing, and critical analysis and evaluation of the scientific literature.

We have also engaged in scientific community outreach activities. We produced short videos on seminal papers in the scientific literature relating to nucleic acids. These videos are geared towards students at the secondary school level. We prepared videos on the topic of the Avery and Griffith transforming principle experiment and the elucidation of the double helical structure of DNA, which were posted on our lab website and are freely available to the public. They are narrated in a conversational and accessible style that highlights the process of performing and reporting research. Our videos provide an entry point to the primary scientific literature and the scientific method for students that are at the beginning of their scientific education.

 


Last Modified: 02/10/2025
Modified by: Ralph Elliot Kleiner
